transcripts.text: Talk to me about Power, man.  We're excited that Power's coming back.  Season six?  Season six.  No!

For us, it's like... It's crazy being on something that everybody calls legendary because you know every scene you shoot is going to be documented.  So that added pressure also makes you feel like, all right, I got to bring my A game every single day.  And so I'm in scenes.  The majority of my scenes was with Omari.  So for me, to me, he's one of the greatest TV actors of all time.  You know what I mean?  So if you slip up, it's going to be exposed.  And so for me, it was a learning process because I never really took an acting class.  So I've learned.  on the spot from greats, you know, and the experience has been amazing.  I think, um, this year for Dre, I'm excited because people get to see the man behind the monster.
I'm glad you said monster.  Yeah.
Because you gotta get shot.  We love you.
You're a great guy.  You gotta die, bro.
The way they killed the other dude, the Spanish dude, what was it, Tito?
Uh, uh, Jay, uh, Julio.  Julio!

The way they call Julio!  Can we show some of our favorite Dre moments?  Because I want to show them, and maybe you could talk just a little bit about what it means to have these powerful moments where everybody hates you.
Yeah, I mean, you know, it's...
Give me the faces you be making.
Yeah, you got to bring it, man, you know?
You look concerned.  Like, you show a range of emotions.
You have to, you have to.
People's families.

Yeah, you were scared.  Then your family almost got ruined.  Yeah, we actually improvised that scene.  I was like, bro, I think instead of just talking about the baby, you should try to hold the baby and, like, move it to the window.  And people are going to feel that.  And so, like, he listened, and we did it one time, so they kept that take, so I was really happy about it.
Wow, and 50s, He's underestimated as an actor.

Oh, yeah, he's dope, man.  He's very, very dope.  He's very methodical in his thinking, and, like, he does everything in his eyes, and that's the number one thing they tell you as an actor.  Really?  Yeah, yeah, he's really dope.
I've seen 50 set on fire.  You know, we've seen him kill.  We've seen a lot of gruesome stuff on Power.  What has been the most shocking, in your opinion, that you've seen throughout the show?
For him?
No, just in general, like, shocking moments.  Raina getting killed.  Like, we got a lot.
I think... I think... So far, in season six, there's something that happens with Dre.  that I think is incredible.
Really?  Yeah, yeah.  Are we gonna like him again?
Yes, your opinion.  Okay, okay, okay.
I mean, you know, it's been in the news.  You and 50 been doing your thing, going back and forth on Instagram.  Come on, man, what we doing?  Don't want to ever take any money from 50 here, please.
I'm not borrowing a dollar from him for the snack machine.  Not even 50 cents.  Exactly.
Don't get 50 cents from 50.  I see what you did there.  So what is going on there?

So basically, I was signed to 50 as an artist.  And so if you're in the music business or if you just have knowledge of how it works is if someone believes in you, they give you a budget to work your project.  So what happened was we didn't agree on the single because he felt like another song off of my project, Walk With Me, was going to be the single.  I said, let me bet on myself.  I think Love Rhythm is the one.  Which is fire.  Yeah.  So he was just like, all right, well... And he's never wanted to hold you back from anything.  He's like, bro, I believe in you.  I know this day is going to come.  So this is before I put the project out.  So I put the project out, and mind you, I still had... Because I got out of my deal early, so I still have a balance that he still put in terms of being his artist.  Right.  So we worked it out where the mechanicals will be paid.  So when you have mechanicals, it's basically saying... the royalties that you make off of your project, that's how he gets paid back.  It's not necessarily out of my pocket.  So the sales off of it.  But the man's a marketing genius, and he's dope the way he does.  And I think, honestly, I think he woke up on the wrong side of the bed that day, because we already had discussed, like, okay, that's how you get it back.  But he's seeing that I bought a house, Yeah, I mean, the record's number one.  So he's like, oh, you can pay it back.  I'm not going to wait for Mechanicals.  Let's pay it back right now.
Did he call you about that?
No, no, no.  We talked days before about, like, man, I'm proud of you.  And so then, again, he's a different breed of beast.  You know what I'm saying?  And you know who he is.

A lot of people thought it was a marketing tool, though.  Like, because it was, like, you dropped the record, it was number one, and then these videos start coming out.  And everybody was like, well, 50 just trying to boost sales and make them even more than number one.  Yeah.  Yeah, but this was a real situation.
No, it was a real situation to a certain extent.  You know what I mean?  Like, it's not a... he's a marketing genius.  But it's also not that I owed him bread.  But he also knew what he was doing.
That's what I'm saying.  Y'all are fine.  Y'all are good.

Oh, that's my brother.  We're good.  You know, it's one of those things where it's like, he's just different.  He's a different breed.  So, like, he does things that can help you, but if you're not smart, it can hurt you.
Were you getting feedback from people, though, like, yo, like, thinking you was broke?  You know, because sometimes when these things happen, you can look crazy on the Internet.

Yeah, I mean, everybody has an opinion.  You know what I'm saying?  So, like, in this business, when you sign that dotted line of any contract, how can I be broke with a number one record?  You know what I mean?  So, like, I just bought a house cash with no mortgage.  You know what I'm saying?  Straight stunting.  Okay.  It's not about that.  It's just to clear up the story.  He just was like, I want my money now because you're popping, bro.  And that's his way of saying, I knew this day was going to happen for you.  Gotcha.  That's what it is.
It's a term of endearment.

That's a weird term of endearment.  I'm proud he wrote it.  He's never been that way.  From day one, it's always like, oh, you popping now?  Pay me my money now.  I've got a house.  Instead of saying it, but he uses the platform also as another way to boost everything as well.
It's a different form of emotion.
